unnormalised: ## Flash Sales: Blink and You'll Miss It!
normalised: ## Flash Sales: Blink and You'll Miss It!

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Ever felt that adrenaline rush when you spot a *killer* deal online, but it's only valid for, like, the next three hours? That's the magic of a flash sale, folks! These super-short sales are a staple in the retail and e-commerce world, and for good reason. They get you scrolling, clicking, and *buying* things you probably didn't even know you needed (no judgement here!).

These super-short sales are a staple in the retail and e-commerce world, and for good reason. They get you scrolling, clicking, and *buying* things you probably didn't even know you needed (no judgement here!).

unnormalised: Think of it like the Diwali discounts at your local Lajpat Nagar market, but amplified and available from the comfort of your couch (with a plate of samosas, naturally!). Businesses, from giants like Flipkart to smaller startups selling handcrafted jhumkas from Jaipur, use flash sales to clear inventory, introduce new products, or just boost their sales figures.

unnormalised: So, why are they so effective? Well, that time pressure is a big part of it. The fear of missing out (FOMO) is a real thing! You see that gorgeous silk saree for Rs. 1500 off and you think, "Hey, even if I don't wear it tomorrow, someone's wedding will come up eventually, right?". Plus, the limited quantities involved often make products feel exclusive. Like getting a seat in the Delhi University North Campus – tough competition, but oh-so-rewarding!

unnormalised: Flash sales are everywhere now. You can find them for everything from electronics (laptops, TVs) to home decor (rugs for your 1200 sq ft apartment). Some even offer travel packages. I remember my cousin, Priya, snagging a ridiculously cheap flight to Goa during a MakeMyTrip flash sale!

unnormalised: Before you get swept away by the hype, remember to do your research. Is that "discount" really a discount, or is the retailer inflating the original price? Read the fine print, check return policies, and don't buy anything you genuinely don't need, even if Dr. Verma, your family physician, swears it's a great deal.
